Description: A fragmentary hollow terracotta figure of Harpokrates, standing, with his finger to his mouth. A cornucopia is in the crook of the left arm; drapery falls over his left shoulder and over a herm upon which he leans. It is very indistinct - the details of the head of the herm are not clear, but indications of its genitals show that it is indeed a herm and not a pier. Harpokrates appears to have a full head of hair and a side-lock; he apparently has a wreath, and wears a Double Crown. Back plain; small circular vent. The right side of the figure is lost. Two-piece mould. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt, with a brown surface. Traces of a white dressing survive inside.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Ptolemaic or Roman, first century BC/AD. Bibliog: Fischer 1994: 271, no. 596.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3047)
